newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel's High Court upholds pork import ban.
newsitem.headline: Israel's High Court upholds pork import ban.

text.p: Israel's High Court on Monday turned down a petition to allow imports of pork and other non-kosher food, upholding a 1994 ban prompted by Jewish religious parties, a court official said.

Israelis, most of whom do not follow Jewish dietary laws, can still buy the non-kosher food rejected by observant Jews since several Israeli collective farms raise pigs and shrimp for the local market.

"I am happy about this ruling because a different ruling would have led to a collapse of the whole public kosher system...so thank God we'll be able to maintain kosher laws in the country," said Chief Rabbi Eliyahu Bakshi-Doron.
The Mitrael meat company had asked the court to disqualify a 1994 law banning non-kosher meat imports on grounds it violated free enterprise and human rights legislation passed in 1992.
The nine-judge panel ruled unanimously that the ban, introduced by religious parties that usually have key roles Israel's governing coalitions, superceded previous legislation.

"The Supreme Court is supposed to be a dam that protects Israeli society from anti-democratic waves, waves that harm human rights and...the dam is not doing its job," said Eyal Erlich, an owner of Mitrael.
